content: How can I help you today?

I’ve been having trouble sleeping lately, and I think it’s because of all the stress I’m dealing with at work. I’m worried about getting fired, and I just can’t seem to shut my brain off at night. My partner insisted I come talk to someone, so here I am.

It takes a lot of strength to recognize when stress is affecting your sleep and well-being, and to take the step to talk about it—so that’s a great start. Work stress can be overwhelming, especially when it leads to worries about job security. What’s been going through your mind at night that’s been keeping you awake?

I just keep replaying everything that’s happened at work—like mistakes I might’ve made or projects I didn’t handle perfectly. I keep thinking about whether I’m going to lose my job and how I’d provide for my family if that happened. It’s like my mind won’t shut off.

That sounds really exhausting, carrying worries about mistakes and uncertainty about providing for your family. It seems like you care deeply about doing well at work and protecting your loved ones, which puts a lot of pressure on you. How do you usually handle stress when it comes up?

I honestly don’t think I handle it well. I try to keep it to myself and push through, but it just piles up. I don’t want to stress out my partner, and with the kids, I try to stay calm so they don’t pick up on it either. Lately, though, I feel like it’s getting harder to keep it all together.

It sounds like you’ve been doing your best to protect your family by keeping things inside, but the weight of it all is becoming harder to manage. It’s commendable that you want to shield them from your stress, yet that’s a lot for one person to carry alone. What do you think might help lighten that load, even if just a little?
I’m not really sure. I guess talking to someone like this is a start, but I don’t even know where to begin. I’ve never really been good at asking for help or opening up about what’s going on with me.

Starting this conversation today is already a brave and meaningful step. Opening up can feel unfamiliar, especially when you’re used to handling things on your own. You don’t have to figure it all out at once—what do you think could make asking for help feel a little easier for you over time?

I guess maybe it would help if I didn’t feel like a burden to anyone by sharing what I’m dealing with. Sometimes I worry that if I open up, I’ll just be stressing people out more, and that makes me hesitate. But at the same time, I know I can’t keep doing this alone forever.

You want to protect the people you care about and make sure you're not placing more stress on them, which shows how thoughtful you are towards others. At the same time, you’re recognizing that sharing what you’re going through could ease the weight you’ve been carrying. How do you think your partner or others close to you might react if you shared a little of what’s on your mind?

You want to protect the people you care about and make sure you're not placing more stress on them, which shows how thoughtful you are towards others. At the same time, you’re recognizing that sharing what you’re going through could ease the weight you’ve been carrying. How do you think your partner or others close to you might react if you shared a little of what’s on your mind?

It seems like you’re unsure how they might respond, but you’re also open to the possibility that sharing could bring some support and relief. Your partner encouraging you to talk to someone may be a sign that they care and want to help. What do you think would be the best way to start that conversation with them?

I think if I were to bring it up, I’d try to keep it simple and just be honest about how I’m feeling. Something like, "Hey, I’ve been really stressed about work, and it’s been a lot to deal with. I just wanted to share that with you." But I still worry that they might feel overwhelmed by it, especially since we’re already juggling so much as a family.

Being honest and straightforward, like you’ve described, sounds like a thoughtful way to open up without adding unnecessary pressure. It’s clear you value your family’s well-being, and sharing your feelings doesn’t mean you’re asking them to solve everything—it’s about letting them support you emotionally. What do you think might happen if you gave that approach a try?

I feel like it could go either way. Maybe they’ll appreciate me talking about it and want to support me, but there’s also a chance they could feel stressed or worried. I just don’t want to add more to their plate, but I know I need to at least try opening up.

It shows a lot of courage and care that you're thinking about both the potential support and the challenges of opening up. Even though sharing comes with uncertainties, it could also bring you closer and offer some relief from the weight you’re carrying. What would make you feel more confident or prepared to start that conversation?

It feels risky, but I think it might help to remind myself that my partner encouraged me to get help in the first place, so maybe they’d be open to talking about it. I guess if I just take it one step at a time, without letting it build up too much, it could be less overwhelming for both of us.

Taking it one step at a time and remembering that your partner already cares enough to encourage you to seek help might be a reassuring starting point. You’re showing thoughtfulness in wanting to make it manageable and open for both of you. Is there anything else you’d like to explore or think through before taking that first step?

Taking it one step at a time and remembering that your partner already cares enough to encourage you to seek help might be a reassuring starting point. You’re showing thoughtfulness in wanting to make it manageable and open for both of you. Is there anything else you’d like to explore or think through before taking that first step?

You seem ready to move forward thoughtfully with sharing your feelings, which is a significant step. Before you start, have you considered whether reflecting on your sleep patterns or maybe your stress levels lately could help you understand how to support yourself better? Would you like to review any recent data to gain some insight?
